instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead

It was actually on when I got it. Shut it down for inspection and it hasn't come back on since. SMC Reset changes the magsafe light, and PPBUS is 8.6v.

There was corrosion on <CHIP>U8005</CHIP>, and <CAPACITOR>C8005</CAPACITOR> right beside it. I replaced both. 

I have PPBUS, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. 

I'm missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>. Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> at BIOS, and missing <SIGNAL>SUS_EN</SIGNAL> as well.

At this point I'm beyond my limited expertise with power issues. Thanks for any advice!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
Check PCH's RTC signals, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>.
Also check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> is 0.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0.00v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> is 1.528v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> IS 3.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
"Check PCH's RTC signals"
You have some time on the forum, should know what I asked for.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

"<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0.00v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> is 1.528v"
Bad signals, both.
Post voltage on both pins of <RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR>.
Check <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> level too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
Ah apologies, thanks for the explanation. 

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> is 3.06v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> is 3.2v

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.4v

<RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR>: 
Pin 1: 3.337v
Pin 2: 3.24v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> is 1.528v
------------------------
<RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR>: 
---
Pin 2: 3.24v"
Are you really sure???
Please, check the schematic and try to understand it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR> is truly 3.24v. <RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR> is 330k as per schematic. Not sure why I got 1.528 before... sorry. 

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is still 0.00v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: Looks like SMC issue, reball it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: I replaced SMC to be safe, no change in voltages on <RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR>. <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> still 0.00v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is high, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> should go high too.
This signal is controlled by SMC, but I suppose the pull-up resistor is inside PCH.
Heat PCH area until 180-200 degrees, for 15-20s; use quality flux, not chinese honey.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: I have AMTECH from Rossman store :) . Done... no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: Force <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> with 10K resistor to <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: Done, 0.035v after the resistor on <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. No change otherwise.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: Did you get SMC from donor board, same model?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: I did yep.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: As last resource, try 470 ohm resistor as pull-up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: Do you mean "Force <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> with 10K resistor to <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>" but with a 470k resistor instead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: NO, I said 470 ohm (0.47K).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message: Ok... desperately searching PDF but no 0.47K resistor on the 3435 donor. Any suggestions for where you would commonly find one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor Liquid Damage, dead
threads.message:
What about 390, 430, 560, 680 ohm???
Anyone can serve here.
